q1.question: If you had a free afternoon, what would you most likely do?

options.text: Try to build a model or fix something broken.
Read a book about animals, plants, or the human body.
Help organize a family event or manage a small budget for a project.
Draw, write a story, or practice music.

q2.question: Which school subject do you find most satisfying?

options.text: Mathematics - I enjoy finding the one correct answer.
Science - I love experiments and seeing how things work in real life.
Social Studies - Understanding how societies and economies function is interesting.
English/Art - I enjoy expressing myself and interpreting creative work.

q3.question: What kind of project would you choose for a science fair?

options.text: Building a simple robot or a working computer program.
Testing how different fertilizers affect plant growth.
A survey on spending habits of students and presenting the data.
Creating a documentary video on a social issue in my community.

q4.question: When playing a game, what role do you usually take?

options.text: The strategist who figures out the rules to win.
The explorer who examines everything in the environment.
The leader who organizes the team and resources.
The creator who makes up stories and characters.

q5.question: Which TV channel would you watch?

options.text: Discovery Science or National Geographic: How it's Made.
National Geographic: Wild or Animal Planet.
A news channel focused on business and markets.
A movie channel or a channel about design and fashion.

q6.question: You win a prize. What do you do with the money?

options.text: Buy a new gadget or tech kit to play with.
Buy a telescope, microscope, or a pet.
Save most of it or think of a small business to start.
Buy art supplies, books, or concert tickets.

q7.question: What is your biggest strength in group work?

options.text: I'm good at solving the technical problems that come up.
I pay close attention to details others might miss.
I'm good at keeping the group organized and on task.
I come up with creative ideas and designs.

q8.question: Which famous person's job seems most interesting?

options.text: Elon Musk (Inventor/Engineer)
Dr. Jane Goodall (Primatologist)
Warren Buffett (Investor)
J.K. Rowling (Author)

q9.question: How do you prefer to learn something new?

options.text: By taking it apart and putting it back together.
By observing it closely in a real-world setting.
By reading a practical guide or a 'how-to' manual.
By watching a video or looking at pictures.

q10.question: What kind of puzzle do you enjoy the most?

options.text: Logic puzzles or Rubik's cubes.
Pattern recognition puzzles (like finding hidden objects).
Crossword puzzles (word-based logic).
Open-ended creative puzzles with no single answer.
When something is inefficient and could be done better.
When people don't care about facts and evidence.
When a project is disorganized and messy.
When people lack creativity or imagination.

q12.question: Which computer game genre do you prefer?

options.text: Strategy or puzzle games.
Simulation games (e.g., farming, life).
Management or tycoon games.
Role-playing games with rich stories and worlds.
A technology expo.
A natural history museum.
A stock exchange or a large corporation.
An art gallery or a historic monument.

q14.question: Your ideal superhero power would be:

options.text: Super-intelligence to invent anything.
The ability to heal any injury or sickness.
The ability to manage and lead anyone to success.
The ability to create illusions or bring stories to life.

q15.question: What is your approach to a big, difficult task?

options.text: I break it down into smaller logical steps.
I research and gather all the information first.
I make a schedule and a plan to tackle it.
I think about the big picture and the end goal first.

q1.question: You have to choose a group for a major project. What do you look for?

options.text: Teammates who are logical and good with technical details.
Teammates who are curious, meticulous, and research-oriented.
Teammates who are organized, practical, and good with numbers.
Teammates who are creative thinkers and good communicators.

q2.question: Which of these real-world problems concerns you the most?

options.text: Developing sustainable energy sources and infrastructure.
Finding cures for diseases like cancer or Alzheimer's.
Addressing poverty and wealth inequality.
Fighting misinformation and improving digital security.

q3.question: What kind of part-time job would interest you?

options.text: Tutoring math or physics.
Working at a pharmacy or a vet's clinic.
Helping out at a family business or a bank.
Freelance graphic design or content writing.

q4.question: How do you handle a subject you find difficult?

options.text: I practice derivations and numerical problems repeatedly.
I create detailed diagrams and flashcards to memorize processes.
I focus on understanding the core concepts and their practical applications.
I try to find a video or a creative analogy to understand it.

q5.question: Which university lab would you most want to tour?

options.text: Robotics or Material Science lab.
Genetics or Microbiology lab.
Trading floor or Economics simulation lab.
Game Development or Animation studio.

q6.question: What is your favorite type of data to work with?

options.text: Numerical data and formulas.
Visual data like cells under a microscope or chemical reactions.
Financial data and statistical trends.
Code, algorithms, or user experience data.

q7.question: Which magazine would you subscribe to?

options.text: Popular Mechanics or MIT Technology Review.
New Scientist or National Geographic.
The Economist or Forbes.
Wired or PC Magazine.

q8.question: Your ideal mentor would be a...

options.text: Chief Engineer at a manufacturing company.
Senior Surgeon or Research Scientist.
Chartered Accountant or Financial Analyst.
Software Architect or AI Researcher.

q9.question: What kind of competition would you enter?

options.text: Math Olympiad or Physics Bee.
Biology Olympiad or Science Bowl.
Business plan competition or stock market challenge.
Hackathon or App Development contest.

q10.question: Which of these skills do you feel is your strongest?

options.text: Spatial reasoning and conceptual thinking.
Memorization and recalling complex information.
Numerical fluency and logical deduction.
Abstract thinking and algorithmic design.

q11.question: What does 'success' mean to you right now?

options.text: Designing something that solves a real-world problem.
Making a discovery that contributes to human knowledge.
Achieving financial independence and stability.
Creating a innovative piece of technology or art.

q12.question: How do you prepare for your exams?

options.text: I focus on practicing every type of problem.
I draw diagrams and create summary sheets of processes.
I understand concepts and practice their application in case studies.
I break down topics into logical structures and understand how they connect.

q13.question: Which documentary would you recommend to a friend?

options.text: The story of the Large Hadron Collider.
A documentary on the human immune system.
An analysis of the 2008 financial crisis.
The history of the internet and Silicon Valley.

q14.question: What kind of internship would be most valuable?

options.text: At a civil engineering firm or an automotive workshop.
At a hospital shadowing a doctor or in a diagnostic lab.
At a chartered accountant's office or a marketing agency.
At a software house working on a small module of an app.

q15.question: Which of these college environments appeals to you?

options.text: A campus known for its rigorous technical workshops and labs.
A campus integrated with a teaching hospital and research centers.
A campus in a business district with strong corporate ties.
A modern campus with state-of-the-art computer labs and innovation hubs.

q1.question: What is the primary driver for your career choice?

options.text: The desire to build, design, and create tangible solutions.
The challenge of solving complex analytical or financial problems.
A deep-seated need to help, heal, and care for others.
The ambition to lead, manage, and drive organizations forward.
The passion to express, communicate, and shape culture.

q2.question: Which professional's daily routine seems most engaging?

options.text: A Software Engineer debugging code and collaborating on sprints.
An Investment Analyst tracking markets and building financial models.
A Doctor making rounds, diagnosing patients, and coordinating care.
A Marketing Manager developing strategies and leading campaigns.
A Journalist investigating a story and conducting interviews.

q3.question: What type of pressure brings out your best work?

options.text: The pressure to meet a technical specification or a tight deadline for a product launch.
The pressure to analyze data accurately for a high-stakes audit or deal.
The life-or-death pressure of making the right decision in an emergency.
The pressure of negotiating a contract or closing a major sale.
The pressure to create a unique and compelling artistic piece on demand.

q4.question: How do you see yourself contributing to society?

options.text: By innovating and building the infrastructure of the future.
By ensuring financial stability and driving economic growth.
By directly saving lives and improving public health.
By creating jobs and leading successful, ethical businesses.
By informing the public, advocating for justice, or creating inspiring art.

q5.question: Which graduate degree has the most appeal for you?

options.text: Masters in Engineering or Computer Science.
Chartered Accountancy (CA) or CFA.
Doctor of Medicine (MD) or Doctor of Pharmacy (Pharm.D).
MBA (Master of Business Administration).
LL.B (Law) or Masters in Media Sciences.

q6.question: What kind of internship is most crucial for your resume?

options.text: A tech internship at a software company.
An internship at an audit firm or bank.
A clerkship or shadowing in a hospital.
An internship in a multinational corporation's business division.
An internship at a law firm, news channel, or advertising agency.

q7.question: Which professional network is most important for you to build?

options.text: With engineers and tech innovators.
With bankers, accountants, and financiers.
With doctors, researchers, and healthcare providers.
With entrepreneurs, CEOs, and business leaders.
With artists, journalists, lawyers, and policymakers.

q8.question: What is your tolerance for years of education?

options.text: 4-5 years for a bachelor's is fine. I'm ready to work after that.
I'm committed to 5+ years, including articleship/training for a professional degree (CA, etc.).
I am prepared for a long haul of 6+ years of education and training (MBBS).
I see myself studying continuously, even after my degree, to stay updated.

q9.question: Which industry trend excites you the most?

options.text: Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning.
FinTech and Digital Currencies.
Personalized Medicine and Gene Therapy.
E-commerce and Global Supply Chains.
Digital Content Creation and Streaming Services.

q10.question: What kind of work-life balance are you seeking?

options.text: Project-based work with intense periods followed by quieter ones.
A standard, predictable 9-to-5 schedule with clear boundaries.
Irregular and long hours, accepting that the job comes first often.
A dynamic schedule that blends social networking with work.
Freelance flexibility, where I control my time but deadlines are sacred.

q11.question: Which professional ethics challenge is most concerning to you?

options.text: The ethical use of AI and data privacy.
Insider trading and conflicts of interest in finance.
Patient confidentiality and end-of-life care decisions.
Corporate social responsibility vs. profit maximization.
Defending a client you know is guilty or biased reporting.

q12.question: How do you handle conflicting information?

options.text: I run tests or simulations to see which information holds up.
I trace the data back to its source to verify its accuracy.
I consult multiple experts and review the latest research.
I analyze which source is more credible based on their track record.
I present both sides and investigate the context behind the conflict.

q13.question: What kind of 'impact' do you want to have?

options.text: Technical impact: My code or design is used by millions.
Financial impact: I help a company become profitable or secure someone's retirement.
Human impact: I directly improve or save a person's life.
Organizational impact: I lead a company to become a market leader.
Cultural impact: My work changes how people think about an issue.

q14.question: Which software tool would you be most interested in mastering?

options.text: Programming languages like Python or Java.
Advanced Excel, SQL, or financial modeling software.
Medical imaging software or electronic health record systems.
Project management tools like Jira or CRM software.
Adobe Creative Suite or video editing software.

q15.question: What defines a 'prestigious' career for you?

options.text: Working for a tech giant like Google or Tesla.
Becoming a Partner at a Big Four accounting firm.
Being a respected surgeon at a top hospital.
Becoming the CEO of a Fortune 500 company.
Winning a Pulitzer Prize or arguing a case in the Supreme Court.

q1.question: You receive critical feedback on a project. Your first reaction is to:

options.text: Thank the person, analyze the feedback for actionable points, and create a revision plan.
Ask clarifying questions to fully understand the concerns before reacting.
Objectively evaluate if the criticism is valid based on data and project goals.
Incorporate the useful feedback and politely discard the rest, focusing on the final goal.

q2.question: A colleague is consistently missing deadlines, affecting your work. You:

options.text: Schedule a private meeting to understand their challenges and offer help.
Clearly communicate the impact of their delays on the project and agree on a new, firm deadline.
Adapt your own workflow to create buffers and minimize the impact on your output.
Escalate the issue to your manager with documented evidence of the delays.

q3.question: You are asked to lead a project on a topic you know little about. You:

options.text: Immerse yourself in rapid research to build a foundational understanding quickly.
Identify and recruit team members who are experts in that area.
Break the project down into manageable parts and tackle the learning step-by-step.
Be transparent about your knowledge gap but confident in your ability to learn and manage.

q4.question: Networking at an event feels to you like:

options.text: An opportunity to learn from others' experiences and share my own.
A necessary part of career building. I set a goal to make 5 valuable connections.
A chance to practice communicating my value proposition clearly and concisely.
Something I prepare for by researching attendees and planning conversation starters.

q5.question: What is your approach to your online professional presence (e.g., LinkedIn)?

options.text: I keep it meticulously updated as a living record of my skills and achievements.
I use it actively to share industry insights and comment on trends.
I see it as a digital CV, crucial for recruiters to find me.
I connect with everyone I meet and use it to maintain a broad network.

q6.question: You have two high-priority tasks from different managers. You:

options.text: Communicate the conflict to both managers and ask them to prioritize.
Assess which task has the tighter deadline or greater business impact and start there.
Negotiate a slight extension on one task by demonstrating your current workload.
Work extra hours to complete both without disappointing either manager.

q7.question: A project you led has failed. In the post-mortem meeting, you:

options.text: Take full responsibility for the outcome as the leader, without blaming others.
Present a clear analysis of what went wrong and the lessons learned.
Focus the discussion on actionable steps to prevent similar failures in the future.
Acknowledge the team's effort and ensure morale is preserved for the next project.

q8.question: You discover a more efficient way to do a routine task. You:

options.text: Document the process and share it with my team and manager.
Implement it immediately to save time on my own work.
Test it thoroughly to ensure it's reliable before presenting it.
Schedule a meeting to demonstrate the new method and its benefits.

q9.question: You are passed over for a promotion. You:

options.text: Request feedback to understand the gaps in my skills or experience.
Analyze the qualifications of the person who got it to set new goals for myself.
Re-double my efforts to ensure my work is undeniable for the next opportunity.
Discuss my career path with my manager to create a clear development plan.

q10.question: What does 'career growth' mean to you?

options.text: Continuous learning and acquiring new, valuable skills.
Increasing levels of responsibility and leadership.
Increasing my compensation and financial security.
Building a strong professional reputation and network.

q11.question: How do you approach a salary negotiation?

options.text: I research industry standards and come prepared with data to justify my request.
I focus on articulating the value and skills I bring to the role.
I consider the entire package (benefits, vacation, growth) not just the salary.
I practice the conversation multiple times to stay calm and professional.

q12.question: Mentoring a junior colleague is important because:

options.text: It reinforces my own knowledge and helps me see things from a new perspective.
It's my responsibility to give back and help others grow, as others did for me.
It builds a stronger, more skilled team, which benefits everyone.
It helps develop my leadership and communication skills.

q13.question: What is your strategy for staying updated in your field?

options.text: I dedicate time each week to read industry publications and journals.
I attend webinars and conferences whenever possible.
I am part of professional forums and online communities where trends are discussed.
I take online courses to earn certifications in emerging areas.

q14.question: You witness unethical behavior at work. You:

options.text: Document the incident with facts and dates before doing anything.
Report it immediately through the official channels outlined by the company.
If comfortable, confront the individual directly to understand their perspective.
Consult the company's code of conduct and then report to my trusted manager or HR.
Setting strict boundaries to ensure my personal time is protected.
Being flexible, allowing work and personal life to blend when necessary, but ensuring overall balance.
Working hard when needed but fully disconnecting during vacations and weekends.
Finding a job I'm so passionate about that it doesn't feel like 'work'.
